resources: "A 5%. ENDSTOPB 7%. ENDSTOPC 8%. ENDSTOPD 10%." "A The demand for Good X to fall and the price of Good X to fall. ENDSTOPB The demand for Good X to fall and the price of Good X to rise. ENDSTOPC The demand for Good X to rise and the price of Good X to fall. ENDSTOPD The demand for Good X to rise and the price of Good X to rise." "A The effect on price is indeterminate but quantity will fall. ENDSTOPB The effect on price is indeterminate but quantity will rise. ENDSTOPC The effect on quantity is indeterminate but price will rise. ENDSTOPD The effect on quantity is indeterminate but price will fall." "A short run excess profits are competed away by firms leaving the industry. ENDSTOPB short run excess profits are competed away by new firms entering the industry. ENDSTOPC short run excess profits lead to price rises. ENDSTOPD short run excess profits are caused by barriers to entry and exit." "A 2%. ENDSTOPB 4%. ENDSTOPC 6%. ENDSTOPD 8%." "A buying a large farm. ENDSTOPB buying another supermarket. ENDSTOPC setting up a number of new smaller outlets. ENDSTOPD buying a car rental business." "A frictional unemployment. ENDSTOPB seasonal unemployment. ENDSTOPC structural unemployment. ENDSTOPD technical unemployment." "A Average physical product is maximised when average physical product equals marginal physical product. ENDSTOPB Average physical product is maximised when marginal physical product is maximised. ENDSTOPC Marginal physical product increases when average physical product is above marginal physical product. ENDSTOPD Average physical product increases when marginal physical product is below average physical product." "A average cost curve. ENDSTOPB average variable cost curve. ENDSTOPC marginal cost curve above the lowest point of the average variable cost curve. ENDSTOPD marginal cost curve above the lowest point of the average total cost curve." "A Perfect competition is distinguished from all other market structures because of the assumption of no barriers to entry/exit from the industry. ENDSTOPB Firms under monopolistic competition face horizontal demand curves for their products. ENDSTOPC A monopoly will find that its average revenue is always greater than its average costs. ENDSTOPD Under perfect competition, in the long run, each firm will find that its marginal cost is equal to its average cost of production." "A When the monopolistically competitive industry achieves a long-run equilibrium, price is greater than marginal cost. ENDSTOPB Monopolistically competitive firms offer differentiated products and face a downward sloping demand curve. ENDSTOPC Under monopolistic competition, the price charged to the consumer is equal to the average revenue of the firm. ENDSTOPD Monopolistically competitive firms can earn supernormal profits in the long run." "A it faces a perfectly elastic demand curve. ENDSTOPB consumers of its product are willing and able to resell their purchase. ENDSTOPC it faces a downward sloping demand curve. ENDSTOPD it is a price taker." "A savings, taxes and investment are withdrawals. ENDSTOPB savings, imports and taxes are withdrawals. ENDSTOPC investment, government expenditure and imports are injections. ENDSTOPD investment, exports and consumption are injections." "A Gross Domestic Product is greater than Gross National Income. ENDSTOPB Gross Domestic Product is less than Gross National Income. ENDSTOPC Gross Domestic Product is the same as Gross National Income. ENDSTOPD We cannot say whether Gross Domestic Product differs from Gross National Income from this information." "A add net income from abroad and deduct transfer payments. ENDSTOPB deduct net income from abroad and add capital depreciation. ENDSTOPC add net income from abroad. ENDSTOPD add net income from abroad and deduct capital depreciation." "A zero. ENDSTOPB £100 million. ENDSTOPC £100 million. ENDSTOPD £500 million." "A £130 million ENDSTOPB £140 million ENDSTOPC £150 million ENDSTOPD £160 million" "A An increase in trade union powers. ENDSTOPB An appreciation of the domestic currency’s exchange rate. ENDSTOPC An increased budget deficit which causes interest rates to rise. ENDSTOPD An increase in the profit margins applied by firms." "A decrease the country’s imports. ENDSTOPB increase the country’s exports. ENDSTOPC shift the country’s currency supply curve in the foreign exchange market to the right requiring central bank purchases of the domestic currency to maintain the fixed exchange rate. ENDSTOPD shift the demand curve for the country’s foreign exchange to the right requiring central bank purchases of the domestic currency to maintain the fixed exchange rate." "A increasing social security benefits ENDSTOPB increasing the money supply ENDSTOPC reducing corporate and personal taxation ENDSTOPD increasing government expenditure aimed at exploiting the multiplier effect" "A small change in the rate of interest and the level of investment. ENDSTOPB large change in the rate of interest and the level of investment. ENDSTOPC small change in the rate of interest and a relatively large change in the level of investment. ENDSTOPD large change in the rate of interest and a relatively small change in the level of investment." "A governments are pursuing an expansionary monetary policy. ENDSTOPB high rates of interest are discouraging borrowing. ENDSTOPC banks are not holding excess cash reserves. ENDSTOPD all proceeds of loans are re-deposited with banks." "A 50 ENDSTOPB 15 ENDSTOPC 10 ENDSTOPD none of the above" "A national income will tend to increase. ENDSTOPB national income will tend to decrease. ENDSTOPD lower domestic interest rates and an exchange rate depreciation."
